definitions: carefully looked after and helped to recover from illness or injury
holding and maintaining particular feelings or thoughts over time
examples: The nursed patient slowly regained strength after surgery
She carefully nursed her injured ankle back to health
He nursed a secret ambition to become a writer
They nursed their grievances for years without speaking

definitions: containing or providing substances necessary for growth, health, and good condition
examples: The nutrient soil helped the plants grow quickly
They added nutrient supplements to improve the feed

definitions: connected with the process of providing or obtaining food necessary for health and growth
examples: The nutritional value of vegetables varies greatly
She consulted a nutritional expert about her diet

definitions: containing substances your body needs to stay healthy and grow properly
examples: She prepared a nutritious breakfast for her children
These nutritious snacks provide essential vitamins and minerals

definitions: crazy or mentally disturbed in an amusing or harmless way
having an extreme enthusiasm or fondness for something or someone
examples: That nuts idea actually worked out perfectly
The whole situation was completely nuts from beginning
She's absolutely nuts about chocolate ice cream
He went nuts when his team won the championship

definitions: having the flavor or containing pieces of edible nuts
amusingly unconventional or eccentric in behavior or ideas
crazy or foolish in a way that seems silly or harmless
examples: The nutty flavor of almonds enhanced the dish
This nutty bread contains three different types of nuts
Her nutty sense of humor kept everyone entertained
That nutty professor has the most interesting teaching methods
The whole nutty scheme fell apart within days
His nutty behavior worried his conservative parents

definitions: complying or willing to comply with orders or requests; submissive to authority
examples: The obedient dog immediately sat when commanded
She was an obedient child who rarely caused trouble

definitions: grossly fat or overweight, typically to a degree that causes health problems
examples: The obese patient required specialized medical equipment
Studies show obese individuals face increased health risks

definitions: arousing distaste or opposition; unpleasant, offensive, or disagreeable to many people
examples: His objectionable behavior at dinner offended everyone present
The committee removed all objectionable content from the report

definitions: not influenced by personal feelings or opinions; considering only facts
existing independently of perception or an observer's mind; external reality
relating to or denoting a goal or aim to be achieved
examples: The journalist maintained an objective perspective throughout the investigation
We need objective evidence before making any decisions
Scientists study objective reality through empirical observation
The objective world exists independent of our perceptions
The objective measures of success were clearly defined
Each objective criterion was carefully evaluated by committee

definitions: restricted to a particular function or mode of life by biological necessity
examples: These obligate parasites cannot survive without their hosts
The obligate anaerobes die when exposed to oxygen

definitions: bound by a social, legal, or moral tie, duty, or promise
legally or contractually required to do something or pay something
examples: She felt obligated to help her elderly neighbor
I'm obligated to attend the family gathering this weekend
The company is obligated to provide safety equipment
Tenants are obligated to pay rent on the first

definitions: required by a legal, moral, or other rule; compulsory and not optional
examples: Attendance at the meeting is obligatory for all members
The obligatory safety briefing lasted thirty minutes

definitions: feeling gratitude for a service or favor; thankful and appreciative
legally or morally bound to do something; having an obligation
examples: I'm much obliged for your generous assistance today
She was obliged by his thoughtful gesture yesterday
Students are obliged to complete all course requirements
He felt obliged to tell the truth about everything

definitions: willing to do a service or kindness; helpful and eager to please others
examples: The obliging staff helped carry our heavy luggage
Her obliging nature made her popular with everyone

definitions: neither parallel nor at right angles; slanting at an angle
not explicit or direct in addressing a point; indirect or evasive
examples: The oblique lines created an interesting geometric pattern
Sunlight fell at an oblique angle through the window
His oblique reference to the scandal confused many listeners
She made oblique criticisms without naming anyone directly

definitions: destroy utterly; wipe out completely leaving no trace
examples: The explosion could obliterate entire city blocks instantly
Time will obliterate all traces of these ruins

definitions: destroyed completely, leaving no trace or remnant remaining
extremely drunk or under the influence of drugs to unconsciousness
examples: The obliterated building was reduced to rubble and dust
The ancient city lay obliterated beneath the desert sand
He got completely obliterated at the party last night
She was too obliterated to remember getting home safely

definitions: not aware of or not concerned about what is happening around oneself
examples: She remained oblivious to the danger approaching rapidly
The child was oblivious to his parents' financial worries

definitions: having an elongated shape, especially rectangular with adjacent sides unequal
examples: The oblong table seated twelve people comfortably
She arranged flowers in an oblong ceramic vase

definitions: extremely unpleasant, offensive, or annoying in behavior, manner, or appearance
examples: His obnoxious comments ruined the entire dinner party
The obnoxious smell from the factory filled the neighborhood

definitions: offensive or disgusting by accepted standards of morality and decency, especially sexually
morally repugnant; deserving moral condemnation for being wrong or evil
shockingly excessive or unreasonable in amount, size, or degree
examples: The obscene material was removed from the public display
They received complaints about obscene language in the show
The dictator's obscene cruelty shocked the international community
Such obscene violence against civilians cannot be tolerated
They paid an obscene amount for that tiny apartment
His obscene wealth contrasted sharply with widespread poverty

definitions: not clearly visible or attracting attention; hidden, indistinct, or dark
not clearly expressed or easily understood; ambiguous or vague
not important or well known; remote from centers of activity
examples: The obscure figure disappeared into the foggy night
An obscure shape moved behind the frosted glass window
The professor's obscure references confused most students completely
The document was written in obscure legal terminology
She studied obscure medieval texts for her doctoral thesis
The band remained obscure despite their musical talent

definitions: able to be noticed, perceived, or detected through observation or measurement
examples: The observable universe contains billions of galaxies
There were no observable changes in patient condition

definitions: quick to notice or perceive things; paying careful attention to details
strictly adhering to the rules or practices of a religion or belief
examples: The observant detective noticed the tiny scratch marks
An observant student spotted the error in calculations
The observant family keeps kosher dietary laws strictly
He remained observant despite living in a secular city

definitions: relating to or based on observation rather than experimentation or theory
examples: The observational study tracked patient outcomes over time
Her observational skills improved with practice and experience

definitions: noticed or perceived through watching or systematic observation
celebrated, kept, or followed as a practice, custom, or tradition
examples: The observed behavior matched our theoretical predictions perfectly
Scientists recorded all observed changes in the experiment
The observed holiday brought families together each year
These observed traditions date back several centuries

definitions: watching carefully and attentively; engaged in observation
following or keeping to rules, customs, or practices
examples: The observing scientists recorded every detail meticulously
She spent hours observing bird behavior in nature
The observing members followed all ritual requirements precisely
They were observing proper protocol during the ceremony

definitions: preoccupied with or constantly thinking about something or someone to an unhealthy degree
examples: He became obsessed with finding the perfect solution
She was obsessed with her appearance and weight

definitions: characterized by or showing excessive preoccupation with something to an unhealthy degree
examples: His obsessive attention to detail slowed the project
She had an obsessive need to control everything

definitions: becoming obsolete; going out of use or no longer serving a useful function
examples: The obsolescent technology was gradually being replaced worldwide
These obsolescent farming methods are rarely used today

definitions: no longer produced or used; out of date and replaced by something newer
examples: The obsolete equipment was sold for scrap metal
These obsolete laws need to be removed from books

definitions: relating to childbirth and the processes associated with pregnancy and delivery
examples: The obstetric ward was equipped with modern monitoring devices
She received excellent obstetric care during her pregnancy

definitions: relating to the branch of medicine dealing with childbirth and maternal care
examples: The obstetrical team prepared for the complicated delivery
Modern obstetrical practices have reduced maternal mortality significantly

definitions: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or chosen course of action despite attempts
examples: The obstinate child refused to eat his vegetables
Her obstinate refusal to compromise delayed the negotiations

definitions: blocked so as to prevent passage, movement, or achievement of something
examples: The obstructed airway required immediate medical attention
Their obstructed view ruined the concert experience completely

definitions: causing a blockage or obstacle that prevents movement or progress
deliberately causing delays or difficulties; being uncooperative and unhelpful
examples: The obstructive growth required immediate surgical removal
Obstructive sleep apnea affects millions of people worldwide
His obstructive attitude made teamwork nearly impossible
The committee faced obstructive tactics from the opposition

definitions: able to be obtained, acquired, or secured through effort or available sources
examples: These rare books are only obtainable through specialty dealers
The permit is obtainable from the local government office

definitions: annoyingly insensitive or slow to understand; lacking sharpness of intellect
of an angle greater than ninety degrees but less than one hundred eighty
examples: His obtuse remarks showed he missed the point entirely
She was being deliberately obtuse about the obvious solution
The obtuse angle measured one hundred twenty degrees exactly
Draw an obtuse triangle on your geometry worksheet

definitions: easily perceived or understood; clear, self-evident, or apparent to everyone
examples: The answer became obvious once she explained it
It was obvious that he hadn't prepared for the meeting

definitions: occurring, appearing, or done infrequently and irregularly; happening from time to time
examples: She enjoyed the occasional glass of wine with dinner
We have occasional meetings to discuss project progress

definitions: involving or relating to mystical, supernatural, or magical powers, practices, or phenomena
not accompanied by readily detectable signs or symptoms; hidden from medical detection
examples: She studied occult practices from various ancient cultures
The bookstore had a large section on occult topics
The occult bleeding required extensive testing to diagnose
Doctors searched for occult infections causing the symptoms

definitions: relating to a job, profession, or occupation and its requirements or hazards
examples: She developed an occupational disease from chemical exposure
The company provides occupational training for new employees

definitions: being used by someone; having an inhabitant or tenant present
busy with or engaged in a particular activity or task
taken control of by military force during war or conflict
examples: All the occupied rooms had their lights turned on
The occupied parking spaces forced us to look elsewhere
She kept herself occupied with various household projects
The children were occupied with their new board game
The occupied territories remained under military control
Life in occupied France was difficult and dangerous

definitions: designed or suitable for traveling on the ocean; capable of ocean voyages
examples: The oceangoing vessel could handle rough Atlantic storms
They purchased an oceangoing yacht for world travel

definitions: relating to the ocean, especially in extent, depth, or distance from shore
examples: The oceanic climate keeps temperatures moderate year-round
They studied oceanic currents and their environmental effects

definitions: of a yellowish-brown color like the natural earth pigment
examples: The ochre walls gave the room a warm feeling
She painted the landscape using ochre and sienna tones

definitions: having eight straight sides and eight angles in geometric form
examples: The octagonal stop sign is recognized worldwide
They built an octagonal gazebo in the garden

definitions: relating to the eyes or vision; performed by or perceived through the eyes
examples: The patient complained of ocular pain and blurred vision
The ocular examination revealed early signs of glaucoma

definitions: different from what is usual or expected; strange, peculiar, or eccentric
of a number not divisible by two; having a remainder when divided
happening or occurring infrequently and irregularly; miscellaneous or various
separated from a matching pair or set; not forming part of a pair
examples: His odd behavior at the party concerned his friends
That's an odd way to solve the problem
Seven is an odd number between two even numbers
Pick any odd number from one to ten
She does odd jobs around the neighborhood for money
He makes odd comments that confuse everyone
She found an odd sock behind the dryer
These odd gloves don't match each other
